title: How to Create an Outdoor Movie Theater

steps.headline: Purchase the PVC pipes.
steps.description:
The frame will be constructed of PVC pipes with a 1.5 inch (3.81 cm) diameter. For this project, these dimensions will make a 4 by 8 ft (1.2 by 2.4 m) screen with a 2 ft (0.61 m) stand. You can ask your local hardware store to cut the pipes for you if necessary. You will need:
2 8 ft (2.4 m) pipes
2 4 ft (1.2 m) pipes
6 2 ft (0.61 m) for the legs (3 for the left-side leg and 3 for the right-side leg)
4 tee connectors (to connect the legs to the screen frame)
2 elbow connectors (to connect the 4 ft (1.2 m) pipes to the 8 ft (2.4 m) pipes
4 caps (to place on the ends of the legs)

steps.headline: Find a white king-size sheet.
steps.description: You can buy a new one from your local home supply store, or you can use an old sheet that you don’t use anymore. Just make sure there are no holes or tears in it. If you’re looking to buy a new sheet, keep in mind that high thread count bedsheets tend to reflect light better than thinner sheets. If you would like a thicker material, buy a piece of canvas drop cloth from your local hardware store. Alternatively, if you don’t want to use a sheet and would like a thicker material, purchase a piece of canvas drop cloth. Make sure it measures at least 8 by 16 ft (2.4 by 4.9 m), because you’re going to fold it over to make a 4 by 8 ft (1.2 by 2.4 m) screen.

steps.headline: Fold the white king-size sheet in half.
steps.description: Fold it so it’s inside-out, meaning that the hemmed seams of the sheet face outward. Use a tape measure to take its dimensions. It should measure to be about 4 by 10 ft (1.2 by 3.0 m).

steps.headline: Lay the pipe with attached elbows along the width of the sheet.
steps.description: Lay out 1 8 ft (2.4 m) pipe (elbow connectors attached!) along the width of the sheet. Use a pencil and a ruler to mark the width of the pipe on the sheet. The elbow connectors will add a small amount of width, and you’ll want to know exactly how wide the screen will be so you can cut our sheet accordingly.

steps.headline: Cut off the excess 2 ft (0.61 m) of fabric on one side.
steps.description: This will make the screen just over 8 ft (2.4 m) wide. It should be able to slide snugly over the PVC pipe frame that you will make.

steps.headline: Hot-glue together the 2 sides of the sheet on each 4 ft (1.2 m) side.
steps.description: Apply a line of hot glue along what will be the height of the screen. Let it dry for up to 2 minutes. This will form a makeshift seam on each side.

steps.headline: Turn your screen right-side out and iron it.
steps.description: Flip your sheet so the seams are facing inward. Iron out any wrinkles, as this could distort any images that are projected onto it.

steps.headline: Assemble the main frame by attaching the pipes with the connectors.
steps.description: Lay out the pieces on the ground in the way that they will be connected. The 8 ft (2.4 m) pieces should be across from each other and the 4 ft (1.2 m) pieces should be across from each other, forming a rectangle. Connect the top corners of the rectangle using the elbow connectors. Connect the bottom corners of the rectangle using the tee connectors.

steps.headline: Attach the pipe pieces for the legs.
steps.description: The legs of your frame will be comprised of the 2 ft (0.61 m) pieces. These pieces will intersect perpendicularly to form 2 right angles. Add on 2 of the 2 ft (0.61 m) pieces to the tee connectors at the bottom of the rectangle. Then, attach your remaining 2 tee connectors to the bottom of the 2 ft (0.61 m) pipes. Place 2 2 ft (0.61 m) pieces in the tee connectors so they stick straight up in the air. Stand your screen upright, and add on the remaining 2 ft (0.61 m) pieces to complete the stand. Secure the 4 caps on the 4 ends of the legs.

steps.headline: Pull the sheet screen down over the PVC-pipe frame so it’s taut.
steps.description: Now, with your frame standing up, fully-assembled, take your sheet screen and pull it over the frame. It’s similar to putting a sock on a foot. Make sure it’s pulled tight so there are no wrinkles. If you measured correctly, it should be pretty taut. If needed, ask a friend to help you, because this can be tricky to do alone! One of the benefits of this particular screen setup is that it can easily be un-assembled and stored until you’re ready to use it next!

steps.headline: Attach black trash bags to the back of your projector with tape.
steps.description: This may not be necessary, but if your sheet is too thin, the light from your projector may pass right through it. To fix this, flatten black trash bags against the entirety of the back of your screen and tape them on.

steps.headline: Buy or rent a projector with HDMI connectivity.
steps.description:
If you are going to be making backyard movie nights a regular summer occasion, it might be wise to invest in a projector of your own. On the other hand, if you’re looking to use a projector once, rent one from a local library or electronic supply store. Get a projector with HDMI connectivity to easily connect your projector to your laptop. Here are some other specs to keep in mind while choosing a projector:
There are currently no projectors that are made exclusively for outdoor use, but most home theater projectors with above 2,000 lumens for brightness and with HD capabilities (i.e. resolutions of 720 or 1080p) will work perfectly. The larger your screen is, the higher resolution you will need. Get a projector with bluetooth capabilities to make your audio system setup a whole lot smoother. Streamline your setup by purchasing a projector that is wifi enabled. These projectors are able to connect directly to apps like Netflix, HBO Go, Hulu, Google Play, or Amazon Instant Video and stream from there.

steps.headline: Connect your projector to your device, if necessary.
steps.description: Use an HDMI cable to connect your laptop to your projector. HDMI cables are pretty inexpensive, so you can easily purchase one from an electronic supply store near you if you don’t have one. There are adapters that you can purchase that will allow you to connect your iOS or Android device directly to a projector with an HDMI cable. If you have one of these, you can project a movie off of your phone!

steps.headline: Adjust the location of your projector until the image is large enough.
steps.description: Do a test run before showing the movie to make sure it will appear the way you want it on the screen. Move the projector closer to the screen if you want to enlarge the image, but move it farther away if you want to make it smaller. Ideally, the projection of the film will fit perfectly on the sheet. Keep in mind that projectors only produce a limited amount of light, so increasing image size usually means decreasing brightness as well. You may need a stand or support of some sort to get your projector at the right height, too. There are special projector stands that you can purchase, but you can also experiment with any furniture pieces or chairs that you might have on hand.

steps.headline: Check that your wifi connection is strong enough.
steps.description: Set up your outdoor theater as close as possible to your wifi router. Then, go to the settings of your laptop or projector and check the strength of your wifi connection. If you’re planning on streaming your movie directly from your projector or laptop, you’ll need a strong wifi connection to stop your movie from buffering all evening long. Some routers support device prioritizing for streaming. Check your router’s settings to see if it has this capability. If it does, prioritize the projector so it gets the best possible connection speed. Speedtest.net by Ookla can tell you exactly how fast your connection is. Run this test from the spot that you would like to set up your theater in your backyard. Netflix recommends a speed of 25 Megabits (Mbps) per second for high-quality HD streaming.

steps.headline: Adjust your projector’s brightness so you can see details in black.
steps.description: If your projector has a “cinema” or “movie” mode, select that. Then, project a scene of the movie that features a lot of the color black. Go to the picture settings menu and push the brightness dial up and down until the image is bright enough, but detail appears in the black areas. For example, if you’re watching the scenes from Gravity that feature a lot of the black space background, you’ll still want to be able to see the stars and smaller details in the black parts.

steps.headline: Balance your projector’s contrast to bring out details in white.
steps.description: Find a scene that features a lot of the color white and adjust the contrast slider until the white parts of the image retain as much detail as possible. Doing this will likely alter the appearance of your black images, so do your best to find a balance where you can discern detail in both colors. With a projected image, black is just the absence of light, whereas white is the addition of it. If your brightness or contrast is off, it can leave black and white parts of images looking like blobs of color rather than objects with details.

steps.headline: Adjust color temperature so actors in the movie don’t look orange.
steps.description: Skip to a scene that features any human. Then, adjust the color temperature slider on your projector until the shade of their skin looks natural. Finding the right color temperature is easiest to do when looking at skin tones.

steps.headline: Invest in a 2.0 outdoor sound system.
steps.description: If you’re looking for your outdoor theater to be a permanent setup, purchase a 2.0 channel stereo system. This system produces 2 channels of sound — left and right. It is generally less expensive than other multi-channel setups and requires the least amount of wiring.

steps.headline: Connect the device playing the movie to your speakers.
steps.description: If you’re using wireless speakers, connect your projector or laptop to your sound system via Bluetooth by going to the Bluetooth option on your device and pairing it with your speakers. If you’re using wired speakers, make sure that your projector and speaker system have compatible AUX ports — meaning that the stereo cables that connect the speakers to the device actually fit in the device. It’s usually not hard to find inexpensive used sound systems at thrift stores or yard sales, but just make sure they can actually connect with your devices. If possible, have multiple speakers placed around the yard so all of your guests can hear the movie. To do this with wired speakers, you will probably need long extension cords so you can connect your speakers back to your device.

steps.headline: Run a sound test before your official movie night.
steps.description: Once you have your speakers hooked up, do a sound test by playing part of your movie on low volume. Gradually increase the volume until it is at a comfortable level where all your guests will be able to hear. If you can, use a speaker system with a separate subwoofer to generate a more dynamic sound. A subwoofer is essentially an air pump that produces low-bass frequencies.

parts.name: Making it Comfortable for Your Guests

steps.headline: Place cushions, blankets, and comfortable chairs around your screen.
steps.description:
Movies are long, so you’ll want to make sure that your guests have a comfortable place to sit throughout. Folding camping chairs or bean-bags work great for this.Image:Create an Outdoor Movie Theater Step 22.jpg
If you don’t have any chairs on hand, you can lay blankets and pillows on the ground. If it’s going to get chilly later in the evening, remind your guests to bring along sweaters.

steps.headline: Have snacks and refreshments available.
steps.description: Adding snacks to your backyard movie night will only enhance it! Popcorn and candy are easy go-tos, but healthier snacks are always a smart idea as well. Some healthy snack suggestions are celery sticks, pretzels, fruit salad, carrot sticks, or crackers and cheese. Purchasing some paper popcorn bags can make it feel just like you’re at the movie theater!

steps.headline: Ward off bugs with citronella candles and bug spray.
steps.description: If you live in an area where mosquitos and other pests tend to congregate, you can keep them away by placing citronella candles around your theater. Just make sure that none of them are close to any flammable objects. Alternatively, you can use traditional bug sprays or creams. Bug sprays often have an ingredient called DEET in them. It’s a powerful insect repellent, but it can irritate your skin, so avoid spraying it directly on your skin if possible.

steps.headline: Do your best to not disturb your neighbors with noise.
steps.description: If you live in a suburban area, you might want to ask for your neighbors’ permission or let them know that you will be doing a backyard movie night beforehand. Or (even better) invite them to join the party! This will give them a heads-up about what you’re doing, and also make them feel welcome in your home. Some areas have noise restrictions imposed by the local government, so be mindful of these.

Run this test from the spot that you would like to set up your theater in your backyard.
Netflix recommends a speed of 25 Megabits (Mbps) per second for high-quality HD streaming.
Adjust your projector’s brightness so you can see details in black.
If your projector has a “cinema” or “movie” mode, select that.
Then, project a scene of the movie that features a lot of the color black.
Go to the picture settings menu and push the brightness dial up and down until the image is bright enough, but detail appears in the black areas.
For example, if you’re watching the scenes from Gravity that feature a lot of the black space background, you’ll still want to be able to see the stars and smaller details in the black parts.
Balance your projector’s contrast to bring out details in white.
Find a scene that features a lot of the color white and adjust the contrast slider until the white parts of the image retain as much detail as possible.
Doing this will likely alter the appearance of your black images, so do your best to find a balance where you can discern detail in both colors.
With a projected image, black is just the absence of light, whereas white is the addition of it.
If your brightness or contrast is off, it can leave black and white parts of images looking like blobs of color rather than objects with details.
Adjust color temperature so actors in the movie don’t look orange.
Skip to a scene that features any human.
Then, adjust the color temperature slider on your projector until the shade of their skin looks natural.
Finding the right color temperature is easiest to do when looking at skin tones.
Rigging up Your Sound System Invest in a 2.0 outdoor sound system.
If you’re looking for your outdoor theater to be a permanent setup, purchase a 2.0 channel stereo system.
This system produces 2 channels of sound — left and right.
It is generally less expensive than other multi-channel setups and requires the least amount of wiring.
Connect the device playing the movie to your speakers.
If you’re using wireless speakers, connect your projector or laptop to your sound system via Bluetooth by going to the Bluetooth option on your device and pairing it with your speakers.

If you’re using wired speakers, make sure that your projector and speaker system have compatible AUX ports — meaning that the stereo cables that connect the speakers to the device actually fit in the device.
It’s usually not hard to find inexpensive used sound systems at thrift stores or yard sales, but just make sure they can actually connect with your devices.
If possible, have multiple speakers placed around the yard so all of your guests can hear the movie.
To do this with wired speakers, you will probably need long extension cords so you can connect your speakers back to your device.
Run a sound test before your official movie night.
Once you have your speakers hooked up, do a sound test by playing part of your movie on low volume.
Gradually increase the volume until it is at a comfortable level where all your guests will be able to hear.
If you can, use a speaker system with a separate subwoofer to generate a more dynamic sound.
A subwoofer is essentially an air pump that produces low-bass frequencies.
Making it Comfortable for Your Guests Place cushions, blankets, and comfortable chairs around your screen.
Movies are long, so you’ll want to make sure that your guests have a comfortable place to sit throughout.

Folding camping chairs or bean-bags work great for this.Image:Create an Outdoor Movie Theater Step 22.jpg
If you don’t have any chairs on hand, you can lay blankets and pillows on the ground.
If it’s going to get chilly later in the evening, remind your guests to bring along sweaters.
Have snacks and refreshments available.
Adding snacks to your backyard movie night will only enhance it!
Popcorn and candy are easy go-tos, but healthier snacks are always a smart idea as well.
Some healthy snack suggestions are celery sticks, pretzels, fruit salad, carrot sticks, or crackers and cheese.
Purchasing some paper popcorn bags can make it feel just like you’re at the movie theater!
Ward off bugs with citronella candles and bug spray.
If you live in an area where mosquitos and other pests tend to congregate, you can keep them away by placing citronella candles around your theater.
Just make sure that none of them are close to any flammable objects.
Alternatively, you can use traditional bug sprays or creams.
Bug sprays often have an ingredient called DEET in them.
It’s a powerful insect repellent, but it can irritate your skin, so avoid spraying it directly on your skin if possible.
Do your best to not disturb your neighbors with noise.
If you live in a suburban area, you might want to ask for your neighbors’ permission or let them know that you will be doing a backyard movie night beforehand.
Or (even better) invite them to join the party!
This will give them a heads-up about what you’re doing, and also make them feel welcome in your home.
Some areas have noise restrictions imposed by the local government, so be mindful of these.
